MOFs have garnered considerable interest owing to their high porosity and precisely engineered molecular structures, making them crucial in gas storage, separation, and catalysis applications. Recently, MOFs based materials have been playing an increasingly significant role in thermal catalytic reactions due to their highly controllable structures and large pores. Therefore, we summarize recent advances in the design, synthesis, and functional applications of MOFs-based materials, including pristine MOFs, composite MOFs, and their derived catalysts through calcination and/or pyrolysis in thermal catalytic reactions (e.g. hydrogenation, oxidation, cascade reaction). Furthermore, we compare the results and summarize the performance differences of different types of MOFs-based catalysts in single organic reactions and cascade reactions, variations in catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. This helps us gain a deeper understanding of the potential applications of MOFs in organic synthesis, and deduce the structure-performance relationships between MOFs materials synthesized from different organic ligands. This review could provide important references for designing and synthesizing efficient catalysts, promoting advancement in the field of thermal catalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Recent advance in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based catalysts (e.g. pristine MOFs, composite MOFs, and their derived catalysts) in thermal single and/or cascade reactions were summarized. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Derivative catalysts Hydrogenation reaction Oxidation reaction Condensation reaction Cascade reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Abbreviations of proper nouns metal organic frameworks, MOFs metal organic layers, MOLs Hong Kong University of Science and Technology-1, HKUST-1 isoreticular metal organic frameworks, IRMOFs, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks materials, ZIFs metarial sofistitute Lavoisier frameworks, MILs pocket channel frameworks, PCNs nanoparticles, NPs hexamethylenetetramine, hmta 4,4′,4′′-s-triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tribenzoic acid, H3TAB S-heptazine tribenzoate, HTB 5′-(4-carboxy-2-nitrophenyl)−2,2′,2′’,4′,6′-pentanitro-[1,1′:3′,1′’-terphenyl]−4,4′’dicarboxylic acid, H3TNBTB 2,4,6-tri(2,4-dicarboxyphenyl)pyridine, H6TDP 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, H2dhbdc 2,4,6-tri-arylpyridines, TAPs 4-dimethylaminopyridine, DMAP N,N-dimethylformamide, DMF 1,3-bis(3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazol-1-yl)propane, BPPP Tert-Butyl hydroperoxide, TBHP 2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl)amino]−1-propanesulfonic acid, TAPs 2-aminoterephthalic acid, NH2BDC 1 Introduction With the continuous progress of the times, the design, preparation, and application of new materials play a vital role in promoting social development and are currently a hot topic of research. In 1995, Yaghi reported a coordination compound with a two-dimensional structure composed of transition metal Co and organic ligand trimellitic acid, and named it MOFs [1]. In recent years, MOFs have emerged as unique porous materials due to their remarkable physical and chemical properties [2]. Formed through the self-assembly of organic ligands and metal ions, MOFs feature highly controllable structures and pore sizes, combining the stability of inorganic materials with the versatility of organic compounds. Their surfaces can be selectively functionalized, enhancing reactivity and selectivity for applications in adsorption, separation, and catalysis. Additionally, MOFs are easy to synthesize, recyclable, and sustainable, offering extensive potential for customized designs and diverse applications [3–8]. MOFs-based catalytic materials are categorized into three types: pristine MOFs, composite MOFs, and derivative MOFs [9]. Comprising organic ligands and metal centers, MOFs exhibit diverse structures, pore sizes, and properties based on the variety of metal ions and ligands used, alongside adjustable synthetic parameters [10–13]. More than 20,000 distinct MOFs have been developed, with common metal centers including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Cr [14], and typical ligands such as carboxylic acids, phosphoric acids, pyridines, and imidazoles. MOFs can be classified into four main categories: IRMOFs, ZIFs, MILs, and PCNs [15]. The integration of MOFs with other materials for high-performance catalytic materials is a significant research focus. MOFs' controllable structure enhances the catalytic effects when combined with materials like metal NPs and nanocarbon. Their large surface area and tunable pore structures improve catalyst dispersion, stability, selectivity, and reaction activity, expanding the catalysts' functional range for various reactions. This research is expected to advance the field of catalytic materials significantly. Additionally, porous carbon-based composites derived from self-templating and precursor-based MOFs maintain the advantages of high specific surface area, enabling the design of multifunctional materials [16–19]. Since 2008, when Xu et al. first prepared porous carbon from MOF-5, numerous metal/carbon catalysts have been developed [20]. These MOFs-derived materials, achieved through high-temperature thermal decomposition, hold great promise for applications in gas storage, catalysis, sensing, and energy storage, highlighting their substantial research value [21–23]. 2 Types of MOFs based materials Researchers are focusing on developing MOFs-based materials, including pristine MOFs, composite MOFs, and catalysts derived through calcination and pyrolysis. Pristine MOFs are pure and unmodified, while composite MOFs combine MOFs with other materials to enhance specific properties. Calcination and pyrolysis transform MOFs into metal-oxide or carbon-based materials with unique catalytic properties, showing promise in heterogeneous catalysis, electro-catalysis, and photo-catalysis due to their tailored structures and active sites. Ongoing research aims to optimize synthesis methods and applications to improve the catalytic performance of MOFs and their derived catalysts [24,25] (Fig. 1 ). 2.1 Pristine MOFs materials The main methods for synthesizing MOFs are solvothermal synthesis, microwave-assisted synthesis, and mechanochemical synthesis [26]. The selection of the synthetic method is typically contingent upon factors such as the desired properties of MOFs, scalability for larger production, reaction time required, energy efficiency, and environmental considerations. Researchers choose the most suitable method based on these criteria to effectively achieve the desired MOFs structures (Fig. 2 ). 2.1.1 IRMOFs IRMOFs consist of interconnected [Zn4O]6+ units and aromatic carboxylate ligands, creating a network with large pores and high volume. The clustering of carboxylate ligands with metal ions can hinder MOFs interpenetration. MOF-5, synthesized by Yaghi et al. in 1999, features a cubic structure with terephthalic acid ligands [27]. MOF-5 is a pivotal MOFs that significantly impacts the field due to its high specific surface area (approximately 2900 m2·g−1), large void fraction (55–61 %), and stability (∼300 °C). Its easy preparation has facilitated research in gas adsorption and energy storage. Recent studies have expanded pore sizes from 0.38 to 2.88 nm using terephthalic acid analogues, resulting in mesoporous MOFs. Additionally, high-temperature calcination can remove zinc to create more porous IRMOFs derivatives, further advancing the field. 2.1.2 ZIFs ZIFs are self-assembled structures made from transition metals (like Zn and Co) and tetrahedrally coordinated imidazole-based ligands. Their M-Im-M framework exhibits a bond angle (∼145°) similar to the Si-O-Si blocks in zeolites. ZIFs have pore structures akin to aluminosilicate zeolites, offering diverse structures and functionalization capabilities, as well as superior thermal and chemical stability compared to other MOFs. Notably, ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, synthesized easily at room temperature, are known for their high stability, combining inorganic zeolite durability with the porosity and organic functionality of MOFs, making them suitable for catalysis and gas separation applications [28]. 2.1.3 MILs MILs materials represent another unique subset of MOFs, using trivalent transition metal ions (such as Fe3+, Al3+, Cr3+) coordinating with carboxylic acid-based ligands (P-phthalic acid, trimesic acid, etc.). MILs also exhibit extremely high specific surface areas. Among these, MIL-100 [29], MIL-101 [30], and MIL-53 are common types. MIL-100 is coordinated with Fe3+ or Cr3+ ions and trimesic acid, maintaining good thermal stability even under high-temperature conditions, with a maximum specific surface area reaching up to 3100 m2·g−1 and a pore size of up to 2.9 nm. In comparison, MIL-101 coordinates transition metal ions with terephthalic acid, achieving a maximum specific surface area of 5900 m2·g−1. MIL-53 mainly consists of octahedral MO4(OH)2 (M usually Al3+, Cr3+, Ga3+, Fe3+, Sc3+) secondary structural units coordinated with terephthalic acid, forming a 3D framework material with 1D rhombic channels [31]. 2.1.4 PCNs The PCNs series of materials predominantly use porphyrins as ligands coordinating with transition metals to form porous coordination networks. Copper ions are common metal nodes coordinated with tricarboxylic acid ligands such as H3TAB or HTB. The PCNs materials contain both pore-type structures and three-dimensional orthogonal channels interconnected through small windows. Compared to IRMOFs, PCNs structures are more complex [32–34]. HKUST-1 is a typical PCNs material. Chui et al. first coordinated Cu2(COO)4 clusters with trimesic acid in 1999 to create HKUST-1. HKUST-1 features two pore structures, one being orthogonal pores, and the other a straight three-dimensional orthogonal channel [35]. Furthermore, these pores share some interconnectivity. From their discovery to the present, the PCNs series of MOFs have found extensive applications in areas such as photocatalysis, drug delivery, and immobilizing biocatalysts. PCNs can be pyrolyzed to form stable M-Nx (M = Cu, Co, Fe, Ni, Mn atoms) single-atom structures, expanding the applications of porphyrin MOFs in the construction of highly efficient single-atom catalysts [36–38] (Fig. 3 ). 2.2 Composite MOFs materials MOFs materials can be composited with silica NPs, zeolite, graphite, various porous materials, covalent organic frameworks, polyoxometalates, ionic liquids, polystyrene spheres, and carbon nanotubes. Currently, the main focus is on summarizing the composites of MOFs with NPs, polystyrene sphere, and Polyoxymethylene (POMs) materials [2,39]. 2.2.1 NPs@MOFs materials The composite MOFs materials with metal NPs leads to the creation of novel multifunctional composite materials. Metal NPs possess high surface energy and superior properties that larger materials cannot match [40]. However, the high surface energy and thermodynamic instability of small-sized metal NPs often lead to aggregation during preparation and reaction processes, leading to poor catalytic performance. Due to the strong coordination between metal and organic ligands and the confinement effect of MOFs structure, metal NPs derived from MOFs are restricted within a narrower range, effectively preventing the aggregation and growth of NPs. This method facilitates the synthesis of highly dispersed metal active NPs, and the catalysts prepared through this method differ from traditional supported metal catalysts as they not only enhance stability but also improve catalytic activity [41–43]. 2.2.2 PS@MOFs materials Polymer microspheres possess several advantageous characteristics, including small particle size, large specific surface area, strong adsorption capacity, good dispersion, and ease of modification, which contribute to their widespread use. Ongoing research has led to a transition in the diameter of polymer microspheres from small to large, as well as an evolution of their morphologies. Notably, monodisperse polystyrene microspheres, derived from styrene monomers, not only retain the benefits of conventional microspheres but also exhibit superior physical and chemical properties such as enhanced stability, strong hydrophobicity, low adhesion, and cost-effectiveness. Monodisperse polystyrene microspheres exhibit good adsorption capabilities, excellent optical/mechanical properties, and high surface activity. One synthetic method of MOFs involves a templating approach, template method is widely used in the preparation of nanomaterials, which can be further divided into soft and hard templating techniques. The key to prepare nanomaterials by template method is template agent Using PS spheres as hard templates, followed by chemical etching to remove the templates, effectively prevents aggregation of NPs on the surface of MOFs, and the potential damage to MOFs from the reducing agent when reducing metal precursors [44,45]. Additionally, in the presynthetic process, precise control over the size and morphology of the NPs can be achieved. By varying the size of the PS sphere template, MOFs structures with different pore diameters can be prepared, expanding the applications of hierarchical ordered porous materials in adsorption and catalysis fields. The highly ordered three-dimensional structure as a template can be applied to the preparation of various ordered large-pore single-crystal materials, resulting in MOFs materials with large pores, high order, tunable pore sizes, and stable monocrystalline structures. These ordered micropore MOFs materials have wide application potential in chemical adsorption or separation, large molecule catalytic conversion, or biomedical drug delivery [46–48]. 2.2.3 POMs@MOFs materials POMs serve as good acid catalysts, containing abundant active transition metal centers and having a unique three-dimensional compound with a special topological structure, making it an excellent transition metal source [49]. However, the limited surface area and poor stability of POMs restrain their development in catalysis. The porous structure and large pore size of MOFs ensure good access of polyanion molecules into the MOFs, while the high surface area and long-range ordered structure of MOFs ensure uniform distribution of POMs [50]. By encapsulating POMs within MOFs to form POMs@MOFs composite structures, the strengths of each party can be maintained, demonstrating strong synergy. The POMs@MOFs composite material combines the advantages of MOFs and POMs, showcasing high porosity, a large surface area, unique crystal and electronic structure. Consequently, they demonstrate outstanding catalytic performance in organic reactions. By dispersing active sites, optimizing nanostructures, synthesizing heterogeneous structures, and incorporating heteroatoms, the quantity of active sites and catalytic activity can be enhanced [51]. Constructing ordered large-pore POMs@MOFs to overcome inherent micropore limitations is important but challenging. On one hand, the introduction of POMs enhances the structural stability of MOFs and modifies their pores. However, the acidic nature of POMs has a substantial influence the nucleation and growth processes of POMs@MOFs composite materials. This strong acidity complicates the synthesis process and makes it challenging to precisely control the assembly. Therefore, researchers need to fully understand these acidic properties in order to better design and control the synthesis process of POMs@MOFs composite materials [52–54]. 2.3 MOFs-derived materials Since most MOFs materials have the characteristic of unstable framework structures, exposing them to acid, alkali, or heat conditions may lead to framework collapse, thereby limiting the prospects of MOFs applications [55]. Given the rich organic carbon and inorganic metal sources in MOFs, using MOFs as precursors or template agents is an effective preparation strategy that can prevent unexpected situations and improve the efficiency of material synthesis and the quality of products. Under pyrolysis in an inert gas atmosphere, MOFs materials can be transformed into stable carbon-based/carbon-nitrogen-based porous materials [56,57]. The materials prepared by this method could retain the high surface area of the original MOFs, as well as maintain the stability of the derived catalysts [58–62]. It is noteworthy that the pyrolysis temperature greatly impacts the final derived catalysts. 2.3.1 MOFs-derived carbon/carbon-nitrogen based materials Conventional nanoporous carbon materials often suffer from lower surface areas, disordered structures, and non-uniform pore sizes, limiting their practical use. However, using MOFs with low-boiling metal elements like zinc as sacrificial materials enables the synthesis of heteroatom-doped carbon-based catalysts through pyrolysis and acid treatment. This method preserves the original MOFs while converting organic linkers into carbon, yielding pure porous carbon without additional carbon carriers or pore-formers. There are two main approaches to preparing metal-free MOFs derived carbon: evaporating low-boiling metal ions during high-temperature pyrolysis or chemically etching metal ions post-pyrolysis. The resulting porous carbon matrix exhibits high surface area, uniform active site distribution, and excellent electrical conductivity, facilitating mass and electron transfer. By selecting suitable MOFs, in situ doping with heteroatoms (N, P, S, B) can be achieved, enhancing material properties. The structure and characteristics of MOFs derived carbon are influenced by factors such as composition, morphology, carbonization temperature, time, and atmosphere, all of which can be optimized to tailor the final material properties for specific applications [63–68]. 2.3.2 MOFs-derived metal, metal oxide, and/or metallic alloy incorporated carbon based catalysts Thermal decomposition of MOFs is an effective method for producing metal-carbon composite materials with uniform metal loading and strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [69]. By calcining metal MOFs at high temperatures under inert atmospheres, various carbon-metal composites can be synthesized. During this process, metal ions can transform into NPs, metal oxides, or hybrid forms, while organic ligands convert into carbon matrices [70,71]. Heat-treated carbon composites maintain some of the original MOFs structure, exhibiting clear pores, high surface areas, and stability in chemical and thermal environments. MOFs made from metals like Al, Ti, and Mg typically yield metal oxide/carbon materials, whereas those with Co, Ni, and Fe produce metal-phase derivatives influenced by reduction potentials [72–75]. Low-temperature calcination in air can also generate metal/metal oxide carbon-based NPs [76–79]. Bimetallic MOFs, created from two different metal ions, enhance stability and catalytic performance due to strong metal-metal interactions. Researchers have explored several strategies to prepare multi-metal MOFs, including simultaneous mixing of metals and ligands, ion exchange reactions, and post-synthetic modifications, allowing for controlled chemical composition and improved functionality [80–84]. 2.3.3 MOFs-derived metal@CN, metal oxide, metal alloy@CN MOFs with controllable pore structures and adjustable compositions serve as excellent platforms for creating various functional nanomaterials. The incorporation of heteroatoms (such as N, P, B, and S) alters the electronic structure, enhancing catalytic activity [85,86]. This doping can introduce defects either directly by adding exogenous heteroatoms or by modifying functional groups to create intrinsic defects. Carbon atom defects can effectively adsorb and stabilize metal ions, resulting in improved dispersion and smaller metal particle sizes. Moreover, these defects modify charge distribution, influencing surface charge states and the adsorption of reactants [87–88]. During pyrolysis, nitrogen doping generates stable nitrogen positions within the carbon framework, such as pyrrole and graphitic nitrogen, leading to enhanced interactions with active components. This results in a larger surface area and increased chemical contact points. Nitrogen incorporation alters surface properties, enhancing electron interactions between the metal and the support, thus promoting electron transfer in catalytic systems. Specifically, nitrogen-rich carbon-supported metal catalysts (M/NC) are promising in heterogeneous catalysis, with ZIFs being ideal precursors for their design [89–95]. 3 Role of metals and ligands in MOFs for production of fine chemicals 3.1 Metals in MOFs for fine chemical production (1) Catalytic Activity Centers: Metals in MOFs often serve as the active sites for catalytic reactions. For example, in many MOFs, transition metals such as Zn, Cu, and Zr are used. In the production of fine chemicals, the metal nodes can act as Lewis acid (LA) sites. In the case of a Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction, a metal-based MOFs with an appropriate metal center can activate the alkylating agent through coordination, facilitating the electrophilic substitution reaction on the aromatic ring. The metal center can polarize the bonds in the reactant molecules, making the reaction more favorable. Some metals in MOFs can also participate in redox reactions. For instance, in the catalytic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes or ketones, a MOFs with a redox-active metal (like Mn or Fe) can provide the necessary electron - transfer pathway. The metal center can change its oxidation state during the reaction, accepting electrons from the alcohol and then transferring them to the oxidizing agent [96–98]. (2) Structural support and stability: Metals play a crucial role in maintaining the overall structure of MOFs. The coordination bonds between metals and ligands form the framework of MOFs. A well-coordinated metal-ligand network provides the MOFs with mechanical stability. For example, in a Zr-based MOFs, the zirconium ions form strong bonds with carboxylate ligands, creating a robust three-dimensional structure. This structural stability is essential for the MOFs to withstand the reaction conditions during the production of fine chemicals, such as high temperatures and pressures or the presence of solvents. The metal-ligand bonds also influence the porosity of MOFs. The size and shape of the pores in a MOFs are determined by the coordination geometry of the metals and ligands. In the synthesis of chiral fine chemicals, a MOFs with a specific pore size and shape can provide a chiral environment for the reaction, which is controlled by the metal-ligand architecture. The pores can selectively adsorb reactant molecules and guide the reaction stereochemistry [99,100]. 3.2 Ligands in MOFs for fine chemical production (1) Functional group introduction: Ligands in MOFs can introduce various functional groups that are directly involved in the production of fine chemicals. For example, ligands with carboxylic acid groups can participate in acid-base reactions. In esterification reactions, the carboxylic acid groups on the ligands can act as proton donors, catalyzing the reaction between alcohols and carboxylic acids to form esters. Ligands with amino groups can also play an important role. They can act as basic sites, for example, in the condensation reactions of aldehydes and amines to form imines. The amino groups on the ligands can interact with the carbonyl group of the aldehyde, promoting the nucleophilic addition reaction. (2) Modulating the chemical environment: Ligands can modulate the chemical environment around the metal centers. The electronic properties of ligands can affect the reactivity of the metal - based active sites. For example, ligands with electron-donating groups can increase the electron density around the metal center, making it more nucleophilic. In contrast, ligands with electron-withdrawing groups can make the metal center more electrophilic. This modulation of the metal center's reactivity can be exploited in the selective hydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons. A MOFs with ligands that tune the metal center to have the appropriate electrophilicity can selectively hydrogenate double bonds over triple bonds, leading to the production of specific fine chemicals. Ligands also determine the hydrophobicity or hydrophilicity of the MOFs internal environment. In reactions involving water-sensitive reactants or products, a MOFs with hydrophobic ligands can protect the reaction from unwanted side reactions caused by water. On the other hand, in reactions that require aqueous media, hydrophilic ligands can facilitate the dissolution and transport of reactants in the MOFs pores [101–105]. 4 MOFs catalysts used for organocatalytic reactions and cascade organic reactions 4.1 Researches on a wide range of organic reactions and their cascade reactions Common organic reactions (e.g. hydrogenation, oxidation, condensation, as well as their cascade reactions) are of great significance in organic chemistry because they allow for the synthesis of a wide variety of compounds necessary for drug discovery, materials science, and many other applications. By understanding and utilizing these reactions, chemists can efficiently and selectively generate into complex molecules with specific properties and functions [106] (Fig. 4 ). 4.1.1 Applications of MOFs based catalysts in hydrogenation reactions MOFs based catalysts are increasingly being applied in the catalytic hydrogenation of various organic compounds, such as olefins, alkynes, alcohols, phenols, aldehydes, carboxylic acids, esters, and other compounds [107–109]. Currently, the main focus is on summarizing the hydrogenation of nitroarenes, furfural, alkynes, and phenol. 4.1.1.1 Hydrogenation of nitroarenes Aromatic amines, produced by reducing nitroarenes, serve as vital intermediates in fine chemicals, widely used in dyes, agrochemicals, and pharmaceuticals. They can be further hydrogenated to form heterocyclic amines, key raw materials for isocyanates and polyurethanes, enhancing their industrial value [110–115].Zhong et al. introduced a "locking effect" strategy for preparing locked MOFs. By modifying ZIF-90 with a long-chain diamine ligand through imine condensation, Au@L-ZIF-90 was created, where the imine chain stabilizes Au NP growth, preventing aggregation (Fig. 5 a). This optimized catalyst shows highly dispersed Au NPs (2.60 ± 0.81 nm, ∼22 wt% loading) and achieves excellent selectivity (99 %) and catalytic conversion (100 %) for nitroarene derivatives. The "lock effect" strategy is also applicable for other metal NPs (Ag, Co, etc.) (Fig. 5b) [116]. Li et al. advanced catalyst design by synthesizing an efficient LaOCl-supported Fe-Fe3C carbon-nitrogen catalyst, Fe-Fe3C-LaOCl/CN-hmta (Fig. 5c). The nitrogen-rich imine groups in La-salen MOFs facilitate the arrangement of metal ions, enhancing catalytic properties. After templated pyrolysis, this catalyst exhibited exceptional activity in nitroarene hydrogenation, achieving 99.8 % conversion and 98.5 % selectivity, outperforming other catalysts. The enhanced efficacy results from the synergistic effects of Fe-Fe3C active sites and LaOCl, which optimize electron transfer and stabilize intermediates [117]. Tang et al. developed a method to create "defective MOFs" precursors for crafting highly porous carbon (HPC)-supported catalysts with tunable secondary pore structures (Fig. 5d). By introducing Ni2+ ions into ZIF-67, which compete with Co2+ for coordination, they generated a coordination mismatch, leading to a "defective structure." Adjusting the Ni2+ to Co2+ ratio allowed control over the HPC's secondary pore structure. The resulting HPCNi-ZIF catalyst features a hierarchical pore structure and exhibits exceptional performance in reducing aromatic nitro compounds, achieving 99.7 % conversion and 100 % selectivity [118]. Gao et al. developed a novel composite material, ZIF-8x@Pd@ZIF-8, which utilizes the unique crystalline facets of a ZIF-8 core to enhance the hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzene (Fig. 5e). These facets improve electron transfer between the ZIF-8 matrix and embedded Pd NPs, resulting in higher positive charge densities on the Pd compared to configurations like ZIF-8TRD@Pd@ZIF-8. This increased charge correlates with enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity for halogenated anilines by optimizing reactant orientation, effectively reducing -NO2 groups while minimizing side reactions [119]. 4.1.1.2 Hydrogenation of aldehydes The hydrogenation of furfural, derived from biomass, is crucial for biomass conversion and sustainable economy. This selective reaction produces furfuryl alcohol, vital for manufacturing crown ethers, adhesives, resins, and fuels. Its downstream product, 1,5-pentanediol, is also an important monomer for polyesters and pharmaceuticals [120–122].Yao et al. developed advanced nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts with a unique three-dimensional ordered macroporous hollow-wall structure, termed H-three-dimensional OM-Co/NC (Fig. 6 a). This innovative material is synthesized from a single-crystal ordered macropore precursor, ZIF-8@ZIF-67, preserving the interconnected macroporous structure through pyrolysis while transforming solid pore walls into hollow structures that host Co NPs. This architecture enhances mass transfer and accessibility of active sites, significantly improving catalytic activity for the selective hydrogenation of biomass-derived furfural to cyclopentanol (Fig. 6b). H-three-dimensional OM-Co/NC outperforms similar catalysts, showcasing its potential in biomass conversion and catalytic applications [123]. Yang et al. developed an efficient method for loading small Pt particles (<2 nm) onto various CeO2 types using atomic layer deposition (ALD). Utilizing MOFs-derived cerium dioxide (M-CeO2) enhanced the uniform deposition and interaction with Pt compared to C-CeO2. The resulting Pt/M-CeO2 exhibited superior catalytic performance, achieving 100 % furfural hydrogenation conversion and 98 % selectivity for furfuryl alcohol, demonstrating the advantages of this deposition approach for efficient hydrogenation processes (Fig. 6c) [124]. Golub et al. significantly advanced mixed-metal MOFs by introducing a one-step solvothermal synthesis for MOF-74. Their research focused on transforming metallic Co, Cu, and mixed compositions (CoxCu1-x) into carbon-supported metal catalysts. By adjusting pyrolysis temperatures and Co to Cu molar ratios (0.33 to 0.95 nm), they synthesized catalysts to optimize catalytic activity. Notably, catalysts pyrolyzed at ≥ 600 °C showed a more complete Cu shell, enhancing catalytic properties for selective hydrogenation. This optimization resulted in an impressive 89 % conversion rate in furfural hydrogenation to furfuryl alcohol [125]. Wu et al. have made significant advancements in catalytic chemistry by developing the modified material UIO-S0.6, which is derived from UIO-66 through the introduction of -SO3H (sulfonic acid) functional groups. This modification enhances the catalytic properties of UIO-66, allowing it to be effectively employed for the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol. The UIO-S0.6 catalyst demonstrates impressive catalytic performance, achieving a remarkable furfuryl alcohol yield of 94.7 % under mild reaction conditions. This high yield is accompanied by a low activation energy of 50.8 kJ·mol−1, indicating that the reaction can proceed efficiently with minimal energy input [126]. 4.1.1.3 Hydrogenation of alkynes The selective hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes is crucial for the polymer, fine chemicals, and pharmaceutical industries. While homogeneous catalysts offer high conversion and selectivity, their irrecoverability limits use. Heterogeneous catalysts, advantageous for separation and recycling, are increasingly favored for this process [127–129].Ling et al. have advanced catalytic materials by introducing a strategy to merge lattice-mismatched MOFs, resulting in "dual-MOFs" that serve as precursors for metal nanoparticle@MOFs composites (MNPs@MOFs) with improved catalytic properties (Fig. 7 a). The HKUST1/ZIF-8 composite enables in situ generation of redox-active Cu NPs in ZIF-8′s hierarchical porous structure through controlled pyrolysis. This design not only supports Cu NP growth but also allows for size modulation, enhancing efficiency and specificity in converting alkynes to alkenes while preventing over-hydrogenation. The innovative Cu@ZIF-8 synthesis highlights the potential of MOFs in advanced catalysis and encourages exploration of other dual-MOFs systems [130].Li and colleagues have made significant advances in catalysis by developing a carbon-supported Ni catalyst with surface and subsurface sulfides, synthesized via a sacrificial MOFs method (Fig. 7b). This innovative approach introduces p-block S elements, enhancing catalyst characteristics and creating highly dispersed Ni sites (Niδ+). The Ni-S/C catalyst's unique composition significantly boosts catalytic performance, improving active site accessibility and electronic properties, leading to superior activity in alkyne hydrogenation. With a conversion rate of 91 % and olefin selectivity of 99 %, the catalyst benefits from structural Ni arrangement and sulfur's role in stabilizing intermediates and facilitating hydrogen transfer mechanisms [131]. Cai et al. contributed to catalyst development by synthesizing carbon-supported Co NPs (C/Co@C) through calcination of Co-MOF-74 at 1000 °C. This innovative catalyst features a protective carbon layer that enhances its selectivity for the semi-hydrogenation of aromatic compounds using sodium borohydride (NaBH4) as the hydrogen source. The graphite carbon acts as a "one-way valve," allowing small borohydride anions to permeate while blocking larger aromatic molecules, thus preventing over-hydrogenation. This design maximizes productivity and highlights the importance of material design in developing selective catalysts, advancing hydrogenation chemistry and setting a foundation for future research [132]. Vasudeva investigated transfer hydrogenation in a non-aqueous medium using ammonia borane (NH3BH3) under both catalytic and non-catalytic conditions. To enhance this process, Pd NPs were immobilized on UiO-66(Hf) MOFs, positioning the μ3 OH groups close to the Pd sites. The synergistic interaction between the μ3 OH groups and the Pd active sites in the Pd/UiO-66(Hf) catalyst achieved over 98 % selectivity for styrene and complete conversion of phenylacetylene at room temperature, outperforming simple physical mixtures of Pd and UiO-66(Hf) or commercial Pd/C catalysts. Density functional theory (DFT) analysis revealed an asynchronous double-H-transfer mechanism from ammonia borane to phenylacetylene, identifying two six-membered cyclic transition states-TS1 (B–H⋯C/N–H⋯C*) and TS2 (B–H⋯C*/N–H⋯C) with free energy barriers of 32.6 kcal mol−1 and 33.4 kcal mol−1, respectively. The reaction is thermodynamically favorable by 43.6 kcal mol−1 (Fig. 7c) [133]. Li et al. developed the bimetallic nanoparticle composite CuPd@ZIF-8, featuring a cubic CuPd core within a porous ZIF-8 shell (Fig. 7d). This configuration stabilizes the core and enhances regioselectivity during catalytic reactions, significantly increasing hydrogenation efficiency when reacting with NH3BH3. The composite proved to be 5 to 105 times more efficient than existing catalysts, highlighting the potential of MOFs combined with bimetallic CuPd NPs for sustainable catalytic processes [134]. Separately, Liang et al. implemented coordination defect engineering in POMs based MOFs, creating three-dimensional frustrated Lewis pair (FLP) catalysts with enhanced performance in alkyne hydrogenation tests (Fig. 7e) [135]. 4.1.1.4 Other hydrogenation reactions Zhang and colleagues have made significant advances in catalyst development by synthesizing hierarchical flower-like nitrogen-doped carbon-coated bimetallic Ni-Co NPs (NixCo@NC@C) using ZIF-67 as a precursor (Fig. 8 a). This catalyst demonstrates superior performance compared to other Ni-Co variants, achieving 100 % selectivity for 2‑methoxy-4-methylphenol while completely converting vanillin, despite fewer exposed metal sites. This selectivity under mild conditions underscores the importance of metal composition and structural arrangement in catalysis [136]. Guo's team developed Cu@NC-ZrO2 catalysts from carbonizing the porphyrin MOFs PCN-222(Cu) at varied pyrolysis temperatures. Their findings show that the carbonization temperature critically influences the structure and catalytic properties. The standout Cu@NC-ZrO2–600 catalyst achieved a 95 % conversion rate in benzyl alcohol hydrogenation with 100 % selectivity, attributed to the synergistic interaction between Cu NPs and active Cu-Nx sites [137]. Yuan's work on Ni@C catalysts derived from defect-rich MOFs highlights the role of a thermally induced decarboxylation defect strategy (Fig. 8b). The Ni@DC-0.06 variant achieved a 95.2 % conversion rate and 97.2 % selectivity for aldehyde in the hydrogenation of nitrocyclohexane, demonstrating the significance of the interaction between defect-rich substrates and Ni NPs [138]. Ma's team synthesized multicomponent nanocatalysts by incorporating transition metals into ZrO2 frameworks via post-synthetic modification using Schiff base ligands (Fig. 8c). The Ni-ZrO2/NC catalyst achieved a remarkable 99.9 % conversion for methyl levulinic acid and 94.7 % selectivity for GVL, showcasing the synergistic relationship between Ni and ZrO2, which enhances the reaction pathway and facilitates intramolecular esterification. These innovative methodologies pave the way for designing highly efficient catalysts for various applications in organic transformations [139]. The catalytic performance comparison of various MOFs based catalysts for hydrogenation reactions has been conducted, as illustrated in Table 1 . Research indicates that ZIFs are more extensively studied, likely due to their straightforward preparation methods. ZIFs offer high surface areas and excellent porosity, enhancing ion transfer rates and improving catalytic efficiency. Among the catalysts examined, Au@La-ZIF-90 exhibits the best performance in hydrogenation reactions, characterized by low reaction temperatures and short reaction times, which can be attributed to the inclusion of the precious metal, gold. However, the scarcity and high cost of precious metals limit further research in this domain. In contrast, Ni and Co have been widely investigated as non-precious metal catalysts. Ni-based catalysts, recognized for their high intrinsic activity, low cost, and ease of generating active species, have been identified as optimal for numerous catalytic reactions. Some alloy catalysts demonstrate performance that rivals that of precious metals, highlighting the need to select efficient, abundant non-precious metal catalysts for selective hydrogenation. All MOFs based catalysts maintain good stability and recyclability during hydrogenation reactions. Notably, Au@La-ZIF-90 retains 89 % yield after 20 cycles, while others, such as CuPd@ZIF-8 and Ni-ZrO2/N-C, exhibit significant performance decline after just 3–5 cycles. This difference may be attributed to the inherent stability of ZIF-90 compared to ZIF-8 or the stronger polarity of the reaction medium, which can lead to the partial dissolution of some catalysts, thereby compromising their cycle performance. Additionally, comparisons with various solid catalysts reveal that while some achieve similar catalytic effects to MOFs based catalysts, others exhibit inferior recyclability. 4.1.2 Applications of MOFs based catalysts in oxidation reactions Organic oxidation reactions play a vital role in the synthesis of various organic compounds and is an important part in the field of organic chemistry. Organic oxidation reactions involve the transfer of electrons from the substrate molecule to the oxidizer, resulting in oxidation of the substrate [149,150]. 4.1.2.1 Oxidation of styrenes Aromatic organic compounds are common indoor air pollutants affecting human health. Styrene epoxidation is a key reaction that produces oxidized styrene, a vital intermediate used in various industries. Enhancing epoxystyrene selectivity in this reaction carries significant practical value [151–153]. Huang et al. integrated Ni and Cu salen into NH2−MIL-101(Cr) through a traditional solvent method (Fig. 9 a). The resultant Cu salen@NH2−MIL-101(Cr) displayed a well-defined porous structure and excellent catalytic activity in styrene oxidation, achieving a 99 % conversion rate and 90 % selectivity for phenylacetaldehyde; higher Cu salen content increased benzaldehyde production [154]. Hu et al. used a direct solvent thermal method to embed transition metal-single-substituted heteropolyacid compounds (TM-HPA) into UiO-66, resulting in TM-HPA@UiO-66 for styrene epoxidation with aldehydes. Notably, Co-HPA@UiO-66 exhibited remarkable catalytic activity, stability, and selectivity under mild conditions, with Co as the primary active site for aerobic epoxidation (Fig. 9b) [155]. Xiao et al. advanced heterogeneous catalysis by synthesizing ultra-thin 2D Cu-phthalocyanine MOFs-based nanosheets for styrene oxidation (Fig. 9c). The 2D Cu-TCPP nanosheets outperformed zinc-based counterparts and traditional crystalline forms, thanks to their high density of active sites and structural accessibility, facilitating efficient reactions. This study highlights the potential of 2D MOFs nanosheets for enhancing reaction efficiencies and selectivities across various catalytic applications [156]. 4.1.2.2 Oxidation of alcohols The conversion of alcohols to aldehydes and ketones is a critical transformation in organic synthesis. Aldehydes, which can be produced by oxidizing primary alcohols, occupy an intermediate oxidation state between alcohols and carboxylic acids. Therefore, selecting appropriate oxidants is essential to control the oxidation process and prevent over-oxidation to carboxylic acids. Secondary alcohols can yield ketones upon oxidation; however, excessive oxidation may lead to molecular cleavage. Additionally, while tertiary alcohol oxidation can result in the formation of ketones, it often involves cleavage and rearrangement reactions, limiting its practical application. Aldehydes and ketones are important compounds with widespread uses in daily life, industry, and scientific research. The rapid oxidation of alcohols serves as a convenient method for producing these valuable intermediates [157–161]. Li et al. have made significant advancements in catalyst development by creating the efficient Cu@UiO-67-BPY catalyst using a one-pot synthetic strategy. This method reduces both the time and solvent required, adhering to green chemistry principles. Their study focused on optimizing catalyst performance by testing different Cu precursors: CuCl2, Cu(OAc)2, and Cu(NO3)2. Notably, the catalyst synthesized from CuCl2 exhibited the best catalytic properties, achieving the highest conversion rates and selectivity for oxidizing alcohols to aldehydes and epoxidizing olefins. This emphasizes the importance of precursor selection in enhancing catalyst effectiveness and highlights the Cu@UiO-67-BPY framework's ability to facilitate selective oxidation processes. The implications of this work are significant for synthetic chemistry, particularly in the sustainable production of value-added compounds. Overall, this research lays the groundwork for developing catalysts that operate under milder conditions without compromising efficiency [162]. Hao et al. explored the innovative utilization of Ce-based MOFs as templates for synthesizing nitrogen-doped porous carbon-coated CeO2 (Fig. 10 a). This hierarchical architecture notably enhances catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. Their studies, backed by DFT calculations, demonstrate that the nitrogen-doped carbon layers significantly improve benzyl alcohol adsorption on the CeO2 surface and reduce the activation energy for the catalytic reaction. The unique three-dimensional structure of the resulting CeO2@N-C ultrathin nanosheets increases accessible surface area and active sites, crucial for enhancing reaction rates and efficiency. Remarkably, this catalyst maintained its performance over five cycles, highlighting its cyclic stability. The findings suggest that engineered materials can be optimized for various catalytic applications, aligning with the ongoing pursuit of environmentally friendly synthetic methods [163]. Wang et al. contributed to the field of catalysis through their synthesis of isostructural mesoporous M-NU-1200 MOFs (where M denotes various metal cations: Zr, Hf, Ce, and Th), focusing on the oxidation of 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol using vanadium based catalysts (Fig. 10b). Their experimental results revealed a substantial difference in catalytic performance based on the choice of metal support, with V-Zr-NU-1200 exhibiting a 20-fold improvement in turnover frequency (TOF) over V-Ce-NU-1200. This study emphasizes the critical role of support material properties in catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, the research identified the electronegativity of metal supports as a crucial factor influencing catalytic activity, where higher electronegativity generally leads to improved interaction with active sites, affecting reactant adsorption and activation. The study's findings suggest that by strategically selecting support materials and optimizing their electronic properties, catalysts can be tailored for enhanced performance in specific reactions. This sets the stage for innovative approaches in catalyst engineering, promoting more efficient and selective processes in various chemical transformations (Fig. 10c) [164]. 4.1.2.3 Oxidation of cycloalkanes In chemical production, the catalytic oxidation of cycloalkanes is essential, generating compounds like cycloalkyl alcohols and ketones that act as crucial intermediates. For instance, the oxidation of cyclohexane yields cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone, which can be further oxidized to adipic acid, a precursor for Nylon-66 and Nylon-6. However, challenges such as low conversion rates and poor selectivity necessitate the optimization of cycloalkane oxidation processes to enhance catalytic efficiency [165–167]. Tang and colleagues conducted a comprehensive study on Zr-MOFs as supports for Fe3+ ions, aimed at enhancing catalytic properties for the photocatalytic oxidation of alkanes. They systematically explored various Zr-MOFs incorporating different secondary building units (SBUs) and pore sizes, characterizing their effectiveness in supporting iron ions (Fig. 11 a). Through post-synthetic metallation, Fe3+ ions were successfully integrated into distinct Zr-MOFs, each displaying a range of Zr-oxo structural units. The varying catalytic activities of the Fe3+-loaded MOFs stem from the interplay between the Zr-oxo units and the substrates and solvents, influencing alkane concentration within the MOF channels while pore size also affects catalytic efficiency. Notably, the MIL140-BPDC-Fe framework demonstrated exceptional photocatalytic performance for cyclohexane oxidation under visible light, achieving a turnover number (TON) of 6914, a conversion rate of 26.2 %, and an apparent quantum yield (AQY) of 5 %. This efficiency indicates the strong alkane oxidation activity of MIL140-BPDC-Fe and its potential in practical photocatalytic applications. The structural characteristics of these MOFs contribute insights into the relationship between molecular architecture and catalytic behavior, paving the way for designing more efficient photocatalysts for specific reactions and expanding the applicability of Zr-MOFs in catalysis [168]. In parallel, Shen and colleagues introduced a novel strategy utilizing catalytic oxidation with O2 to enhance selectivity and conversion rates of cycloalkanes into valuable alcohols and ketones. Employing metal porphyrins as effective catalysts and Zn(AcO)2 to facilitate the conversion of cycloalkyl hydroperoxides to cycloanols, this approach preserves selective outcomes while minimizing unwanted cycloanones (Fig. 11a). Through careful management of reaction conditions, the synthesis maximizes desired product yield and minimizes less useful byproducts. This methodology emphasizes the potential of metal-organic complexes for efficient chemical transformations under mild conditions, with implications for organic synthesis, pharmaceuticals, and industrial chemistry, ultimately contributing to greener and more sustainable processes [169]. 4.1.2.4 Other oxidation reactions Li et al. conducted a comparative study of MOFs, specifically MIL-101(Al) and MIL-101(Fe), for the immobilization of the active component H3PMo6W6O40. They incorporated Fe3O4 to impart magnetic properties, resulting in the catalyst Fe3O4@NH2−MIL-101-POM (Fig. 12 a). This catalyst was employed in the desulfurization of DBT using air as the oxidant. Notably, Fe@NH2−MIL-101(Fe)-POM achieved a remarkable conversion efficiency of 100 % within 60 mins, utilizing a smaller amount of catalyst and allowing for increased recycling cycles. This superior performance is attributed to the larger surface area of MIL-101(Fe), which facilitated the binding of more active components, enhancing their contact with DBT [170]. Sun and colleagues demonstrated a significant advancement in catalysis by using heterogeneous POMs integrated into MOFs for the direct aerobic iodination of arenes. The catalyst, PMoV2@MIL-101, was synthesized using a straightforward one-pot method, encapsulating POMs within the stable and highly porous MIL-101 framework. The PMoV2@MIL-101 catalyst achieved complete conversion of mesitylene to 2-iodomesitylene, with a reaction rate comparable to traditional homogeneous POMs systems (Fig. 12b). This illustrates the effectiveness of MOFs as supports for POMs in reactions typically requiring homogeneous catalysts. Notably, the iodination reactions occurred without the need for auxiliary catalysts or sacrificial agents, aligning with green chemistry principles to minimize waste and environmental impact [171]. Li and colleagues also synthesized symmetrical Th6−MOFs with various metal complex units and Th clusters for photocatalytic applications. Their research focused on the photocatalytic oxidation of methyl phenyl sulfide, revealing the enhanced control over conversion rates and selectivity provided by functional metal complexes (Fig. 12c-e). Among the synthesized frameworks, the Ni-PBA-Th6 catalyst exhibited an impressive conversion rate of approximately 99 % and a selectivity of 97 %, highlighting its practical value by favoring desired oxidative products. This work underscores the potential of Th6−MOFs in photocatalysis and paves the way for future studies in catalysis and related fields [172]. As shown in Table 2 , carboxylic acid-based oxidative MOFs based catalysts exhibit exceptional catalytic performance in organic oxidation reactions, thanks to their highly crystalline and tunable structures. The abundant active carboxyl groups on their surfaces serve as reactive sites that facilitate reaction progress. Notably, Zr-based MOF catalysts and MOFs encapsulating POMs have significantly enhanced catalytic oxidative performance. These catalysts demonstrate good activity, selectivity, and cyclic stability, leading to high efficiency in the oxidation of organic substrates. Furthermore, the tunable porous structure and surface functional groups of MOFs enable optimization of catalytic performance through structural adjustments, expanding their potential applications in organic oxidation reactions. In comparison to some solid catalysts, it is evident that most solid catalysts exhibit inferior cyclic stability when compared to MOFs based catalysts. MOFs based catalysts can maintain their performance after 4 to 15 cycles, while solid catalysts typically do not demonstrate comparable cyclic stability. This highlights the superior enduring nature of MOFs based catalysts in facilitating oxidation reactions over multiple cycles. 4.1.3 Applications of MOFs based catalysts in condensation reactions Condensation reaction (e.g. Knoevenagel, Adol, Friedlander) is the basic reaction of organic chemistry. With the demand for high-quality development in the field of chemistry and chemical engineering, the total synthesis of various fine chemicals, pharmaceutical products, functional polymers and various important drug intermediates can be prepared by condensation reaction [178]. 4.1.3.1 Knoevenagel condension reactions The Knoevenagel condensation reaction is a widely utilized method in organic synthesis, akin to the Aldol reaction, where a carbon atom accepts an alkyl group as a catalyst (Fig. 28). This reaction typically involves the direct interaction of an aldehyde with an active methylene compound, such as methanol or other methylating agents, under basic conditions, leading to the formation of unstable α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds. This reaction is crucial for synthesizing organic molecules that contain α,β-unsaturated carbonyl structures, which are important in drug and natural product synthesis [179,180]. Yang and colleagues synthesized several zinc-based MOFs through reactions between Zn2+ salts and amino acid derivatives, namely Val-X (where Val = N-(4-pyridylmethyl)-l-valine; X = Cl−, HCOO−, CH3COO−) and Ala-X (where Ala = N-(4-pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine; X = Cl−, HCOO−). The resulting pristine Zn-MOFs display a unique hexacoordinate structure, providing stable amine and carboxylic acid sites. These Zn-MOFs were employed as heterogeneous catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation reactions with a variety of aldehydes, exhibiting high catalytic activity under mild conditions (Fig. 13 a). Specifically, when utilizing a water-to-ethanol volume ratio of 1:1 at room temperature, five Zn-MOFs based on pyridine amino acid derivatives achieved high yields of up to 96 % in these reactions [180]. Zhang et al. contributed significantly to catalyst development by designing a nitro-functionalized organic ligand, H3TNBTB, which led to the synthesis of a robust cobalt MOFs, named (NUC-82a) (Fig. 13b). This framework features a tri-nuclear cobalt cluster as a secondary building unit, distinguished by a rich array of Lewis basic (LB) sites, essential for catalytic activity. NUC-82 demonstrates exceptional efficiency in catalyzing Knoevenagel condensation reactions, particularly between aldehydes and malononitrile, highlighting its potential for practical applications. Furthermore, NUC-82 exhibits high selectivity and outstanding recyclability, allowing for effective reuse without significant activity loss, making it practical for synthetic processes. Zhang et al.'s work emphasizes the potential of nitro-functionalized ligands in designing effective catalytic frameworks, marking NUC-82 as a promising candidate for sustainable catalysis in future applications [181]. Liu et al. unveiled a highly durable microporous framework, denoted as {(Me2NH2)2[Pb5K(TDP)2(μ2 OH)]·4DMF·6H2O}n (NUC-45). Synthesized by combining an S-shaped heterometallic cluster with the organic ligand H6TDP (1,3,5-tri(carboxy)benzene), NUC-45 is structured around unique lead-cluster and potassium cation-based secondary building units. This framework's well-defined porosity and LA sites, alongside basic sites introduced by μ2 OH groups, contribute to its reactivity and functional capability. NUC-45 has shown remarkable catalytic efficacy in two key reactions: the cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 and the Knoevenagel condensation of aldehydes with malononitrile (Fig. 13c), indicating its potential application in CO2 conversion and organic synthesis, both critical for sustainable chemistry. The incorporation of K+ ions enhances the stability and catalytic performance of MOFs, reinforcing NUC-45′s effectiveness in these reactions [182]. Zhang et al. also explored the synthesis of a hybrid material, [Cu2(BPPP)2]{θ-[Mo8O26]} (NUC-62), using a self-assembly approach that merges electron-rich POMs with electron-deficient MOFs. This hybrid material exhibits significant physicochemical stability and ample coordination sites, contributing to its catalytic capabilities. NUC-62 displays outstanding activity in promoting Knoevenagel condensation reactions, highlighting the effectiveness of its open metal sites and abundant terminal oxygen atoms (Fig. 13d). The open metal sites facilitate substrate activation, enhancing the catalytic process of forming carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds. This research underlines the significant role of material design in advancing catalysis, furthering the potential applications of MOFs and hybrid materials in sustainable chemistry [183]. 4.1.3.2 Aldol condension reactions The aldol reaction, commonly known as aldol condensation or hydroxide aldehyde condensation, is vital in organic chemistry, particularly for synthesizing complex molecules. This reaction produces a new CC bond by linking two carbonyl compounds, yielding β‑hydroxy aldehydes or β‑hydroxy ketones. When subjected to heat, these compounds often dehydrate to form α-unsaturated carbonyl compounds. Aldol reactions can be categorized into self-condensation, where identical carbonyl compounds react, and crossed condensation, involving different carbonyl compounds. This versatility allows for diverse synthesis pathways for β‑hydroxy compounds, such as 1,3-propanediol and 1,3-butanediol, which are useful in producing fragrances, pharmaceuticals, and polymers. The condensation products derived from α,β-unsaturated aldehydes can be oxidized to yield carboxylic acids, key raw materials in the fine chemical industry. Selective hydrogenation of α,β-unsaturated aldehydes can also yield saturated aldehydes, widely used in solvents, detergents, and plasticizers. Thus, leveraging the aldol reaction enhances organic synthesis while facilitating the production of essential chemicals across various industries. In summary, the aldol reaction offers numerous pathways to construct complex molecules from smaller carbonyl precursors, serving as a fundamental reaction in both academic research and industrial applications [184,185]. Zhu et al. innovatively fabricated MOFs integrating amino acid-derived chiral moieties. Utilizing acidic modulators to control the cavity size of Zr-UiO-66-NH2, they anchored the amino acid-thiourea motif within these cavities, achieving high yields that significantly enhanced catalytic activity and enantioselectivity. The mild reaction conditions minimized the racemization risk during thiourea formation, preserving chirality integrity. The Zr-UiO-66-NHCS-Pro catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance in the asymmetric aldol reaction using 4-nitrobenzaldehyde and acetone, achieving notable enantioselectivities. Zhu et al. reinforced the need to tailor MOFs pore sizes to optimize catalytic environments, confirming that adjusted cavity dimensions enhance catalyst activity and selectivity. Their findings pave the way for future innovations in chiral catalysis by illustrating the relationship between MOFs structure, reaction conditions, and catalytic efficacy [186]. Chen et al. developed a mixed truncation method to synthesize defect-engineered chiral MOFs with hierarchical micro/mesoporous structures. This strategy produced defect chiral MOFs, specifically DCCuBTC-0.6, achieving the highest enantiomeric excess (ee) of 56.5 % in aldol condensation reactions (Fig. 14 a). Their results highlighted the significant impact of pore size on chiral MOFs efficacy; larger pore volumes enhance the flexibility of chiral active molecules, facilitating efficient chirality transfer to reactants and improving selectivity. Defect chiral MOFs exhibited superior enantioselectivity compared to conventional microporous MOFs, mainly due to their larger pore volumes providing greater spatial freedom for chiral configurations [187].Cesar et al. conducted a comprehensive study on monometallic and bimetallic UiO-66 nanocatalysts, utilizing solvothermal synthesis. These nanocatalysts were evaluated for their performance in aldol condensation reactions involving benzaldehyde and acetone (Fig. 14b). Bimetallic UiO-66 catalysts containing Zr and Hf displayed a synergistic effect that enhanced reaction rates, attributed to these metals' complementary electronic and structural properties, achieving yields of 97.9 % for benzalacetone. In contrast, bimetallic catalysts with Zr and Ce exhibited reduced activity due to free carboxylic acid formation during synthesis. Overall, these findings underscore the importance of metal selection and interactions in catalyst performance, highlighting Hf's beneficial role in Zr-UiO-66 for efficient cross-coupling condensation reactions [188]. Ghaedrahmat et al. explored the synthesis of composite materials by integrating Faujasite-type zeolite with ZIF-8 MOFs, enhancing ZIF-8′s chemical stability. They utilized environmentally friendly methods at room temperature to create Faujasite zeolite/ZIF-8 nanocomposites exhibiting high acidity and refined microstructures essential for catalytic applications. These composites demonstrated impressive stability and catalytic performance, achieving over 90 % yields in esterification and aldol condensation reactions under solvent-free conditions. Their findings indicate that these composites maintain catalytic activity over multiple cycles, positioning them as viable options for sustainable industrial processes [189]. 4.1.3.3 Friedlander condension reactions The Friedlander condensation, also known as Friedlander quinoline synthesis, is essential for synthesizing quinoline compounds, which are significant in developing anticancer drugs. Quinoline compounds exhibit therapeutic effects through mechanisms such as cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, angiogenesis inhibition, and regulation of growth inhibitors. They also find applications in dye production, photosensitive materials, rubber, solvents, and chemical reagents [190,191]. Subhrajyoti et al. reported on UiO-66(Hf)-(NHCOMe)2 (1) and its activated form (1′). This UiO-66 framework is formed by coordinating Hf4+ ions with 2,5-diacetamidoterephthalate linkers, creating a structure where the central Hf4+ ion coordinates with multiple µ3 O and µ3 OH sites. The activated catalyst 1′ was effective in the Friedlander condensation of phenacylamine and acetylacetone, achieving an 86 % yield of the product 1-(2,4-dimethylquinolin-3-yl)ethan-1-one. The purification process involved solvent exchange to remove impurities, ensuring the catalyst's effectiveness in yielding quinoline derivatives in quantitative yields under mild conditions [192]. Aniruddha et al. developed a hydrazine-functionalized Hf-UiO-66 (Hf-UiO-66-N2H3) using a solvent-thermal method, enhancing catalytic activity. The activated form 1′ exhibited a remarkable 95 % yield of 3-acetyl-2,4-dimethylquinoline in the Friedlander condensation at 100 °C with 2-aminoacetophenone and acetylacetone. Comparatively, hydrazine-functionalized MOFs (1′) outperformed other functionalized and non-functionalized MOFs due to additional Brønsted acidic sites, which facilitate proton transfer and increase substrate reactivity. This study highlights the significance of tailoring functional groups to enhance catalytic performance in organic transformations [193]. 4.1.3.4 Other condension reactions Fu et al. synthesized six distinct nanomaterials by combining MNPs with MOFs to create core-shell structures, subsequently introducing amino groups through post-synthesis modification (PSM). This study is notable for the first-time exploration of MNPs/MOFs core-shell structures as catalysts in the condensation reaction between benzaldehyde and 1-heptanal, where the amino functional groups significantly improved catalytic yield. The γ-Fe2O3-AA/Al-MOF-A catalyst demonstrated advantages over traditional homogeneous KOH catalysts, including shorter reaction times, environmental friendliness, and recyclability. Future work will involve further examination of MNPs/MOFs core-shell materials and comprehensive comparisons with various traditional catalysts [194]. Neumann et al. focused on the one-step synthesis of Guerbet alcohols from linear alcohol precursors using MOFs-derived RuCo alloys as catalysts (Fig. 15 a). Their research showcased significant turnover rates for the Guerbet reaction with 1-propanol, 1-butanol, and 1-pentanol, using a highly reactive catalyst produced in situ by impregnating MFU-1 MOFs with Ru. The study highlighted the selectivity of the MOFs-derived catalyst, with RuNi NPs favoring the production of linear alcohols, especially 1-butanol (Fig. 15b). The catalytic performance was enhanced by incorporating Na2O2 or K3PO4 as promoters, while infrared spectroscopy revealed modifications in the electronic environment of Ru in the MOFs matrix that may contribute to altered catalytic activity [195]. Pattraporn et al. advanced the synthesis of 5,7-dihydroxy-4-methyl-coumarin using sulfonic acid-functionalized MOFs (UiO-66-SO3H) as catalysts. Their findings indicated that UiO-66-SO3H markedly reduced the activation energy for the Pechmann condensation reaction to 12.6 kcal.mol−1, compared to 22.6 kcal.mol−1 for standard UiO-66, emphasizing the effectiveness of sulfonic acid groups in enhancing catalytic efficiency under milder conditions, beneficial for green chemistry [196].Neumann et al. also demonstrated the efficiency of a MOFs derived RuCo catalyst for converting 1-butanol into 2-ethylhexanol, an important plasticizer, by utilizing air-stable pre-catalysts and replacing NaOBu with K3PO4 to improve yields and minimize unwanted byproducts (Fig. 15c) [197]. MOFs as catalysts have shown promising prospects in various common condensation reactions. In this study, we compared the MOFs-based catalysts used in the condensation reactions (Table 3 ). It was observed that MOFs based catalysts with LA or LB sites are more effective in catalyzing Knoevenagel condensation reactions. NUC-82a, NUC-45a, NUC-62, and ValZnCl, which possess abundant LA and LB sites, maintained good catalytic activity. In the table, two sets of data showed lower yields, possibly due to current limitations in the exploration of Guerbet alcohols. Although the conversion rate in the reactions is good, selectivity is always accompanied by the production of other by-products. Dc-CuBTC-0.6, a chiral MOFs, achieved a conversion rate of only 66.5 % at low temperatures, but with an ee value as high as 56.5 %. 4.1.4 Applications of MOFs based catalysts in cross-coupling reactions The activation of C-X bonds in aryl halides (ArX) plays a crucial role in organic synthesis. Coupling reactions are essential pathways in organic chemistry for efficiently constructing C-C, C-N, and C-S bonds, facilitating key reactions such as the Suzuki reaction, the Wurtz reaction, and the Heck reaction. Coupling products like C-C and C-N bonds, along with their intermediates, dominate industrial production and hold significant application potential in various fields such as pharmaceuticals, fertilizers, and chemicals. Here, we primarily discuss the Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions, Heck coupling reactions, and Sonogashira coupling reactions [207–209]. 4.1.4.1 Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions In 1979, A. Suzuki and N. Miyaura reported a pivotal reaction involving 1-alkenylboranes and aryl halides, catalyzed by a Pd catalyst, leading to the formation of aryl-substituted (E)-alkenes. This reaction, later termed the Suzuki coupling reaction, allows for the cross-coupling of aryl or alkenyl boron compounds, such as boronic acid esters, with halides or triflate esters under Pd catalysis. The Suzuki coupling reaction has solidified its position as one of the most effective methodologies for synthesizing diaryl compounds, demonstrating remarkable substrate adaptability. It is widely employed for the synthesis of polyenes, styrenes, and biphenyl derivatives, further extending its application to the synthesis of numerous natural products and organic materials [210,211]. Recent advancements in this field include Mohammadniai's development of a copper-based catalyst, wherein Cu is immobilized on the MOF 2-(5-aminopyrimidin-2-yl)pyrimidin-5-amine (CuAPPA·2H2O)n. This innovative catalyst offers several advantages such as straightforward preparation, easy separation, environmental friendliness, high yields, and good reversibility. When employed in Suzuki reactions for synthesizing aryl compounds, the (CuAPPA·2H2O)n catalyst delivered yields of up to 96 % of biphenyl under mild conditions, with a minor decline to 91 % after four cycles [212]. Liu and colleagues achieved notable progress by synthesizing novel Schiff base imidazole-functionalized MOFs using PSM methods (Fig. 16 a). They successfully anchored small Pd0 clusters (averaging 1.5 nm) onto the MOFs, resulting in the Pd0@UIO-66-SB-Im catalyst, which demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance in Suzuki coupling reactions between halobenzenes and phenylboronic acids, achieving yields exceeding 99 % under mild conditions. The small size of the Pd0 clusters enhanced catalytic activity by increasing their surface area, while the MOFs' tailored design facilitated the stabilization and distribution of these clusters, optimizing catalytic performance through controlled electronic properties. This catalyst showcased high substrate compatibility and maintained its yield across six cycles, where it consistently achieved 99 % yields. Liu's work exemplifies how functionalized MOFs can be strategically designed to improve catalytic efficacy and sustainability in Suzuki coupling reactions [213]. Daniele Cartagenova introduced the innovative Pd P-MOFs, a molecularly defined heterogeneous catalyst framework based on phosphine MOFs. This catalyst demonstrated remarkable performance in Suzuki reactions under mild conditions, exhibiting selectivity that surpassed that of traditional homogeneous catalysts like Pd(PPh3)4. The enhanced selectivity of Pd P-MOFs indicates potential for cleaner reaction profiles with reduced byproducts and yields around 65 %. Its versatility enabled effective catalysis across various substrates, facilitating coupling reactions involving diverse aryl and vinyl halides with boronic acids, thus broadening access to valuable biaryl and complex organic compounds. This work emphasizes the potential of leveraging unique materials for improved catalytic performance [214].Eugenia and her team contributed significantly to catalysis with the introduction of Pd2+ centers into the MOFs MUV-22 through a solvent-assisted reaction using a Pd-metalloligand. The ordered arrangement of Pd atoms within MUV-22 and its high chemical stability positions it as a promising catalyst for Suzuki-Miyaura alkylation reactions (Fig. 16b). The MUV-22 catalyst effectively facilitated C-C bond formation between a variety of boronates and allyl bromides, showcasing versatility and efficiency while maintaining activity over multiple cycles without losing crystallinity. This resilience is crucial in heterogeneous catalysis, where deactivation is a common issue. The potential for MUV-22 to open new avenues in heterogeneous catalysis aligns with the goals of sustainability and efficiency in synthetic chemistry [215]. Wu and colleagues developed an innovative catalyst featuring highly dispersed Pd nanoclusters anchored on nanostructured Pd@HfO2. This catalyst, synthesized through a two-step pyrolysis process with Hf-based MOFs, demonstrated exceptional efficiency in the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction, achieving over 99 % catalytic activity with bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid. The Pd@HfO2 catalyst exhibited remarkable stability, maintaining catalytic performance across at least ten cycles, benefiting from the formation of ultra-small Pd nanoclusters and optimal acidic sites in the HfO2 support. The reaction mechanism was detailed into four major steps involving oxidative addition, ions substitution, transmetalation, and reductive elimination, reaffirming the structural integrity of the catalyst as confirmed by XRD analysis (Fig. 16c-d). Wu's research highlights the advantages of nanostructured catalysts in achieving sustainable and efficient catalytic processes. These advancements collectively underscore the significant progress in utilizing functionalized MOFs and Pd-based catalysts to enhance the efficiency and sustainability of Suzuki coupling reactions, paving the way for future innovations in organic synthesis and catalysis [216]. 4.1.4.2 Heck cross-coupling reactions The Heck reaction is one of the most prominent methods for forming C-C bonds in organic chemistry. This reaction allows for the synthesis of substituted alkenes through the coupling of olefins with aryl or vinyl halides (or triflates) under basic conditions. It is characterized by high regioselectivity and stereospecificity, showcasing versatility in accommodating various substrates, including simple olefins, aryl-substituted olefins, electrophilic olefins, and N-allyl amides. Its significance extends across organic synthesis, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and materials science, making it a valuable strategy for producing functionalized alkenes through transition metal catalysis, particularly utilizing Pd, Cu, and Ni [217–220]. Hassan Keypour and his team advanced the field by synthesizing functionalized MOFs embedded with Pd NPs, leading to the creation of UMCM-1-NH2-furfural-Pd. This innovative material was synthesized through a series of well-defined steps, which included the PSM of UMCM-1-NH2, an amino-functionalized MOFs. Furfural was grafted onto the MOFs framework via a Schiff base reaction, allowing for the stable complexation of Pd2+. The characterized UMCM-1-NH2-furfural-Pd demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity in both Suzuki and Heck coupling reactions, which are critical for forming C-C bonds. The high surface area of the MOFs provided ample active sites for Pd NPs, enhancing catalyst accessibility. Additionally, interactions between the LA sites generated by the Zn nodes of the MOFs and the Pd2+ ions stabilized the Pd NPs while increasing their reactivity. Keypour's research highlights the potential of combining MOFs chemistry with targeted functionalization to create high-performance catalysts for complex organic transformations, paving the way for future exploration of advanced catalytic systems [221]. Dang and colleagues synthesized a novel Pd-incorporated Zr-based MOFs, designated as Pd(II)@BUT-11, by dispersing sulfonyl-functionalized MOFs in a Pd(OAc)2 solution. This catalyst effectively facilitates Suzuki coupling reactions between styrene and iodobenzene-a common pairing in biaryl compound synthesis and pharmaceutical production. Notably, the use of a deep eutectic solvent (DES) derived from 1,4-diazabicyclooctane further enhanced the reaction's efficiency. DESs are viewed as environmentally friendly solvents, offering low toxicity and high solvating capacity while promoting reactions by increasing yield and efficiency. The Pd(II)@BUT-11 catalyst exemplified recyclability, maintaining performance over five cycles, which aligns with sustainable chemistry principles by reducing waste. The use of a DES also minimized reliance on traditional organic solvents, positioning Dang's work as a significant advance in sustainable catalytic processes within organic synthesis [222]. Zheng and colleagues focused on enhancing catalytic performance by creating a dipolar microenvironment within a MOFs structure by incorporating DMF fragments (Fig. 17 a). The modified MIL-101-DMF exhibited solvent characteristics similar to DMF, which has implications for catalytic applications. By embedding Pd NPs within this structured framework, referred to as Pd@MIL-101-DMF, the researchers effectively improved Heck reaction outcomes in low-polarity solvents. Traditional Heck reactions can struggle with efficiency in non-polar environments; however, the dipolar microenvironment stabilized transition states and intermediates, resulting in a catalytic efficiency increase. The yield of ethyl cinnamate reached 90 %, demonstrating the enhancements attributable to the specially engineered MOFs (Fig. 17b) [223]. Wu and colleagues developed the Pd/MIL-101-PPh3 catalyst by integrating MOFs technology with covalent ligand attachment. By anchoring PPh3 ligands to the MIL-101 framework-a MOFs recognized for its high surface area and tunable pore structure—they successfully immobilized Pd NPs onto the MOFs surface. Rigorous evaluations, including spectral analyses and DFT calculations, demonstrated that the PPh3 ligands increased the electron density of the Pd NPs, facilitating the activation of carbon-halogen bonds in aryl halides. The catalyst performed exceptionally well in multiple catalytic transformations, outperforming several benchmark catalysts in Suzuki-Miyaura and Heck reactions (Fig. 17c). This work underscores the potential of integrating MOFs with covalent ligand chemistry to create high-performance catalysts for essential organic transformations [224]. Srinivasulu and colleagues synthesized a novel Cu-MOFs, which was subsequently transformed into an efficient heterogeneous catalyst (Pd-MOF) through a post-synthesis method. The modified Pd-MOFs exhibited considerable catalytic activity in C-C bond formation by cleaving C-N bonds in arylhydrazines. Analysis revealed the presence of two distinct Pd2+ environments within the MOFs framework-a tetrahedral site coordinated by pypz ligands and a square planar site interacting with di-pyrazole nitrogen atoms and chloride ions (Fig. 17d). Investigating the porous characteristics of both Cu-MOFs and Pd-MOFs indicated promising adsorption capacities, marking advances in the development of effective solid-state catalysts for C-C couplings (Fig. 17e) [225]. These collective efforts illustrate the ongoing innovation in the design and application of MOFs in catalysis, particularly in enhancing efficiencies and sustainability in C-C coupling reactions. The integration of various modifications and strategies not only improves catalytic performance but also aligns with green chemistry principles, paving the way for the future potential of MOFs in diverse catalytic applications. 4.1.4.3 Sonogashira cross-coupling reactions The Sonogashira coupling reaction is a critical cross-coupling method involving organic halides and terminal alkynes, which are significant in synthesizing pharmaceuticals, natural products, and materials. This reaction, first demonstrated by Professor Sonogashira, effectively creates substituted alkynes from aryl, heteroaryl, and vinyl halides, with iodine and bromine-substituted hydrocarbons showing the highest reactivity. Typically catalyzed by Pd and Cu in a basic amine solvent, the Sonogashira reaction has become a fundamental tool in organic synthesis [226–229]. Recent advancements in this field include Esmaeil and colleagues' development of a heterogeneous Pd catalyst system, Pd-NHC-MIL-101(Cr), immobilized on MOFs modified with N-heterocyclic carbene. This catalyst demonstrated excellent performance in Cu-free Sonogashira reactions, achieving a 94 % yield of 1,2-diphenylethyne under mild conditions, with 89 % efficiency maintained over six cycles. The robust stability of this catalyst was confirmed by minimal Pd and Cr leaching [230]. Shirin Karimi and colleagues introduced supported noble metal catalysts, Au and Pd, on an iron-based MOFs modified with an ionic liquid.
